topics: Co-operative and Adaptive Algorithms Fall 2024
ECE 457A
• Huda Diab Abdulgalil: Email hdiababd@uwaterloo.ca
The course starts by addressing the ill-structured problems and need for computational intelligence methods.
It introduces the concepts of heuristics and their use in conjunction with search methods, solving problems using heuristics and metaheuristics, constraints satisfaction.
The course also introduces the concepts of co-operation and adaptations and how they are influencing new methods for solving complex problems.
The course starts by illustrating how the concepts of co-operation and adaptation are manifested in nature and how such models are inspiring new types of solutions methods.

Topics to be covered include search algorithms, game playing, constraints satisfaction, meta-heuristics, evolutionary computing methods, swarm intelligence, ant-colony algorithms, particle swarm methods, adaptive and learning algorithms and the use of these algorithms in solving continuous and discrete problems that arise in engineering applications.

View requirements for ECE 459
Many modern software systems must process large amounts of data, either in the form of huge data sets or vast numbers of (concurrent) transactions.
This course introduces students to techniques for profiling, rearchitecting, and implementing software systems that can handle industrial-sized inputs.
These techniques will enable you to design and build critical software infrastructure, especially in an age of Big Data.
While you may have seen some of these ideas in the context of operating systems (ECE350/SE350/CS350/MTE241) and concurrency (ECE252/CS343), this course gives you tools to make code run faster.

A course to develop the understanding required to simulate complex fluid flows, such as those found in turbo-machines, duct systems, and other engineering hardware.

Course topics include the physics of complex viscous fluid flows, first- and second-order finite control volume discretization methods, iterative algorithms for the solution of sparse matrix equation sets, including multi-grid acceleration, boundary condition modelling, two-equation and Reynolds stress turbulence models, and grid generation techniques.
Computational fluid dynamics software is used throughout the course to simulate and analyze complex fluid flows relevant to engineering applications.

Topics include design and construction of retrieval systems, retrieval models, and evaluation of search engines.
Search engines and recommendation systems are prevalent in society.
Recommendation systems are a variant of search engines and are often found in shopping and media sites, e.g. Amazon, TikTok, Spotify, YouTube, and Netflix.
The methodology for optimization and evaluation, as covered in the course, is applicable to both classical and the most modern of retrieval methods.

The programming assignments are cumulative and require working software from the previous assignment to make the subsequent assignment also work.

The numbers in the parathesis refer to the Engineering Graduate Attributes defined by the Canadian Engineering Accreditation Board (CEAB):

A knowledge base for engineering: Demonstrated competence in university-level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
Problem analysis: An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation: An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

Design: An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural, and societal considerations.
Communication skills: An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking, and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism: An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Impact of engineering on society and the environment: An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions, and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Life-long learning: An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

Course Introduction An introduction to the teaching team, course expectations, deliverables, marking scheme, and a very brief introduction to interfacing concepts.
Embedded Systems A review of fundamentals of embedded systems and the terminology associated with embedded systems.
Embedded Design Model An introduction to the embedded design model used to develop a system for the remainder of the course.
Embedded Software An overview of they key differences between software for embedded systems and general software development.
Synchronization, Data Generation and Data Transfer A model for analyzing synchronization behaviour and performance and examples of synchronization analysis.
Buses - Data Transfer A comparison of the functional behaviour and timing behaviour of synchronous, asynchronous, and partially interlocked asynchronous.
Parallel Interfacing A detailed examination of the design of parallel interfaces.
This includes an examination of the role of the interface in matching bus timing and signaling characteristics with a device's timing and signaling characteristics.
Analog Interfacing An introduction to digital-to-analog interfacing, analog-to-digital interfacing, and sample-and-hold circuitry.
This includes a comparison of asynchronous communication techniques and synchronous techniques as well as the protocols for serial communication.

Buses - Arbitration A brief examination of alternatives for bus arbitration including a discussion of the operation and characteristics of daisy chained and non-daisy chained bus arbitration techniques.
A brief examination of direct memory access including a discussion of hardware design implications, software implications, and system performance.
Security and Ethics An overview of common security terminology and why it has become increasingly important for embedded systems.
The ethical implications of today’s embedded systems applications will also be discussed.

Fundamentals of autonomous mobile robotics, including both perception and planning for autonomous operation, sensor modelling, vehicle state estimation using Bayes Filters, Kalman Filters, and Particle Filters as well as onboard localization and mapping.
Topics in planning include vehicle motion modelling and control, as well as graph based and probabilistic motion planning of (Micro Electro Mechanical Systems) MEMS devices.
This course covers four fundamental topics of Autonomous Mobile Robotics; 1) modeling, 2) sensors and perception, 3) estimation (localization and mapping), 4) planning and navigation.
Modeling covers kinematic models of various types of wheeled mobile robots.
Sensors include various types and algorithms (for vision and range sensors).
Estimation includes Bayesian estimation theory and its application to localization (and/or mapping).
Topics in Planning include odometry motion models and graph-based and probabilistic motion planning as well as obstacle avoidance (reaction-based) methods.

Advanced methods for systems of linear equations.

This course introduces the applications of optimization modeling and numerical methods to various engineering optimization problems.
It provides an overview of the formulation and classification of optimization problems arising in engineering and types of suitable optimization methods.

Graphical solution methods for two-variable problems and optimization techniques for single-variable problems like region elimination approaches, interpolation algorithms, and direct root-finding methods are discussed.
Linear Programming problem formulations and simplex and interior-point methods for solving such problems are discussed.

This course approaches the design of tasks, tools, products, and systems from a user-centered design perspective.
Emphasis is on the human factors and usability methods, and techniques that can and should be applied throughout the iterative design process.
Major topics include user research methods for usability and user experience, inspection methods, user testing, applied statistical analysis.
SYDE 548 (UCD Methods) approaches the design of tasks, tools, products, and systems from a user-centered design perspective.
Emphasis is on the human factors and usability methods, and techniques that can and should be applied throughout the iterative design process.
Major topics include user research methods for usability and user experience, inspection methods, user testing, and applied statistical analysis.
SYDE 548 User-Centred Design Methods is a technical elective.
It builds from earlier SYDE core courses in design (SYDE-BME 161 Introduction to Design, SYDE-BME 162 Human Factors in Design, and SYDE-BME 361 Engineering Design).
Motivated students willing to become familiar with basic human factors engineering can participate and contribute to course activities.

course_name: STV208 - Artificial Intelligence and Society: Impact, Ethics, and Equity (0.50)
topics: Artificial Intelligence and Society: Impact, Ethics, and Equity Winter 2025
The objective of this course is to introduce students to ethical and social concerns relating to Artificial Intelligence (AI).

By understanding the basic principles of AI and its evolution, to engaging with complex issues like algorithmic bias and privacy concerns, this course offers a comprehensive look at both the promise and challenges AI brings to society.

Through real-world case studies, students will analyze how AI systems influence industries, economies, and governance while learning to apply ethical frameworks that ensure fairness and accountability in AI deployment.

The course is designed to not only equip students with the tools to evaluate the societal impacts of AI critically but also to empower them to actively engage in discussions about the future of technology and society.
By the end of the course, students will be prepared to make informed contributions to the ongoing debates about the role of AI in shaping the future.

Identify and explain key concepts related to the societal impacts of AI technologies, including ethical considerations, biases, and privacy concerns, and classify real-world examples where these issues arise.
Compare different ethical frameworks and governance models for AI, and critically test their effectiveness in addressing issues such as fairness, accountability, transparency, and human rights.

Evaluate the broader implications of AI on democracy, human rights, and socioeconomic systems, and assess how AI-driven innovations can either support or challenge social equity, ethical standards, and global governance structures.
8 Socioeconomic Impacts of AI and Automation Mar 5 Mar 11
12 The Future of AI: Ethical Design and Responsible Innovation Apr 2

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,
know how to classify differential equations,
know how to solve various classes of differential equations using numerical methods and exact methods, and

This is a fast-paced survey course (covering about one textbook chapter per week) introducing a wide range of topics in modern physics.

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.

What does it mean to be a cell biologist?
One group of scientists might explore growing tissues in a laboratory to one day produce artificial skin or organs.

No matter what their question, cell biologists use a similar set of laboratory skills that allow them to peek inside the tiniest of biological units that make up the diversity of organisms we see around us.

Although fundamental techniques like microscopy have hugely advanced since the invention of the light microscope, every cell biologist needs to learn how to properly use a microscope to see cells reliably.
These can be very tricky to use properly but doing so could be the difference between a world-changing discovery and an experiment that no one can replicate.
These and other methods that are integral to working in the cell biology field will be introduced in this laboratory and it is my hope that you will leave confident in these fundamental techniques.

Coverage includes hypothesis testing and the nature of scientific inquiry, basic population genetics, physiological ecology, life histories, dispersal, basic population and community ecology, macroevolution, systematics and classification, as well as functional morphology.
The theory of evolution unites the whole of biology and all living organisms into a coherent body of knowledge, allowing comparisons across all forms of life.
Ecology describes how organisms interact with their environment and each other to create interdependent systems from microscopic to global scales.

These disciplines are fundamentally tied together: evolution is the primary mechanism by which species adapt to their environment; ecological interactions and environmental variability drive natural selection.

You will also carry out simulated lab assignments to test the principles of evolution, design ecological experiments to test alternate hypotheses about the conservation of species and manipulate demographic parameters to test their influence on population growth.
Understand the principles of scientific methodology
Define ecological and evolutionary terms, such as the niche, adaptation, and altruism
Illustrate these mechanisms in the context of course examples
Explain how ecological interactions and evolution are interconnected
